elements.title: Concierge Warmth — The Agent's Voice as Emotional Template
elements.problem: Theodore responded most positively when the agent said 'I am your concierge' (10:45) and 'we pay a lot of attention to our customers being happy' (10:49-11:01). The UI has no equivalent emotional warmth — it's functional but impersonal. The gap between the agent's warm, personal tone and the platform's transactional interface creates an emotional drop-off when the guest moves from phone to screen.
elements.solution: Infuse the agent's concierge tone into UI copy throughout the pre-lease journey. (1) Replace 'Submit Proposal' with 'Send Your Interest'. (2) Replace 'Matching in progress' with 'Robert is finding your best options.' (3) Replace 'No results found' with 'We haven't found your perfect match yet — Robert is expanding the search.' (4) Every status update should name the agent, use first person, and communicate care. The emotional target: the guest should feel like the app is Robert speaking to them, not a system processing them.

evidence.quote: I am your concierge... we pay a lot of attention to our customers being happy.
evidence.insight: The 'concierge' label instantly elevated Theodore's engagement. He responded 'I appreciate that' — this is the emotional quality the UI must replicate.

evidence.quote: Establish a Positive Persona... Change Your Vocabulary.
evidence.insight: Greever says the persona you project determines how people receive your message. The UI's persona must be 'knowledgeable concierge' not 'processing system.'

elements.emotion_rationale: Theodore's emotional arc went from confused (00:24) to confident (14:09) entirely through the agent's tone. The UI must replicate this arc: from 'I don't understand this' to 'I'm in good hands.'

do: Name the agent in status messages
Use 'we' and 'your' instead of passive voice
Include one conversational aside per screen ('We think you'll love this neighborhood')
dont: Use generic greetings ('Welcome, user' or 'Hello there')
copy_guidelines.example_good: Robert found 3 spaces that match your weekend pattern. Take a look when you're ready — no rush.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: 3 listings match your search criteria. Review results to proceed.

animation_feel.feel_description: Gentle arrival, like someone placing a cup of coffee in front of you. Nothing slides in aggressively; everything settles into place.

tension_relief.tension_point: After submitting a proposal and entering the 2-3 week wait
tension_relief.relief_point: First status update from the named agent, even if just 'Robert received your interest and is reviewing it'
tension_relief.timing: Relief must arrive within 1 hour of submission. Even if no matching has occurred, the acknowledgment is itself the relief.

personalization_signals: Agent's name and photo in all status messages
Guest's preferred days reflected back in contextual language

anti_patterns.pattern: Generic system messages without a human sender
anti_patterns.reason: Destroys the concierge feeling that Theodore responded to. System messages feel like a queue; agent messages feel like care.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Your proposal has been submitted. You will be notified when there is an update.

elements.title: Fair Deal Satisfaction — Make the Guest Feel Smart, Not Cheap
elements.problem: Theodore eagerly signed up for the 40% discount tier (12:07), but the framing matters enormously. 'You get a discount because you clean' can feel degrading. 'You're saving 40% because you're flexible and responsible' feels empowering. The agent framed it as a trade: 'for less flexibility and willing to do some chores, you get a 40% discount.' The UI must maintain this 'smart trade' framing throughout the lease, especially during weekly cleaning submissions.
elements.solution: Frame every discount-related interaction as a smart decision, not a cost-cutting compromise. (1) Replace 'Discount tier' with 'Smart Stay tier' or 'Flexible Guest tier.' (2) Savings communications should feel like congratulations: 'Your flexibility saved you $X this week. Smart move.' (3) Cleaning submissions should feel like responsible ownership: 'Space Care confirmed. Nina will appreciate coming home to a clean space.' (4) Never use language that implies the guest is getting a lesser experience — they're getting a BETTER deal because they're a better guest.

evidence.quote: For less flexibility and willing to do some chores, you get a 40% discount.
evidence.insight: The agent framed the discount as a fair TRADE. The emotional quality is 'fair deal' — both sides give and both sides get. The UI must maintain this equity framing.

evidence.quote: Shows respect. You value everyone's opinions and time enough that you're well prepared.
evidence.insight: Greever's 'respect' principle: the UI must respect the guest's effort by framing it as valuable, not as a cost-saving obligation.

elements.emotion_rationale: The guest chose the discount tier because they felt smart about it. Weekly interactions must reinforce that feeling: 'I made a good choice' not 'I have to do chores to save money.'

do: Frame savings as the guest's achievement ('You saved')
Acknowledge the trade-off as a smart decision
Show the host's appreciation for the guest's effort
dont: Use words like 'discount', 'cheap', 'basic' for the tier
Frame cleaning as a requirement or penalty
Compare to non-discount guests ('Unlike Premium guests, you must...')
copy_guidelines.example_good: Space Care complete. You saved $82 this week by keeping the space in great shape. Your total savings: $738.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Cleaning photos submitted. Your discount has been applied for this billing cycle.

animation_feel.easing: ease-out with slight overshoot on savings counter
animation_feel.feel_description: The savings number should land with a satisfying 'ka-ching' quality — not literally a sound, but the visual equivalent: a number that arrives with emphasis and settles confidently.

tension_relief.tension_point: End of stay, when the guest knows they need to clean and submit photos
tension_relief.relief_point: Savings counter animation after photo submission — the effort is immediately rewarded with a visible dollar amount
tension_relief.timing: Savings reveal within 2 seconds of photo upload confirmation

personalization_signals: Show the specific dollar amount saved THIS week (not just percentage)
Reference the host by name in appreciation context
Cumulative savings milestones ('You've saved enough to cover a whole extra week!')

anti_patterns.pattern: Framing cleaning compliance as a requirement with penalty for non-compliance
anti_patterns.reason: Transforms the 'smart trade' feeling into 'wage labor' feeling. The guest should never feel like they're working for the discount.
anti_patterns.example_bad: WARNING: You did not submit cleaning photos last week. Your discount may be revoked.

elements.title: Confusion-to-Clarity Arc — Every Screen Should Resolve One Question
elements.problem: Theodore started the call confused ('Now I am confused' at 00:24) and ended confident ('I really appreciate our chat and I'll be in touch' at 14:09). This emotional arc happened because the agent resolved one confusion at a time, never piling on. The UI, by contrast, presents ALL information at once — listing details, pricing, rules, photos, schedule — creating cognitive overload that maintains confusion rather than resolving it.
elements.solution: Design each screen/section to resolve ONE question before introducing the next. (1) Discovery: 'What is SplitLease?' → resolved by the comparison strip. (2) Listing page: 'Does this match my needs?' → resolved by the match quality indicator. (3) Pricing section: 'Can I afford this?' → resolved by the personalized monthly total. (4) Protection section: 'Am I safe committing?' → resolved by the protection shield. Each section should feel like a conversation turn: question → answer → next question. This is Greever's 'set the context' principle applied to every UI section.

evidence.quote: From 'Now I am confused' to 'I really appreciate our chat.'
evidence.insight: The emotional arc is confusion → understanding → confidence. Each question resolved builds toward the next. The UI must replicate this sequential resolution.

evidence.quote: Set the Context... Optimize for Memory... Remove Distractions.
evidence.insight: Greever's meeting design principles: set one context at a time, make each point memorable, remove everything that doesn't serve the current question.

elements.emotion_rationale: Each resolved question produces a micro-moment of relief. The cumulative effect of 4-5 micro-reliefs is confidence. Without the sequential resolution, the guest stays in a state of unresolved confusion.

do: Start each section with the question it answers
End each section with a transition to the next question
Use progressive disclosure — don't answer questions the guest hasn't asked yet
dont: Use tabbed interfaces that require the guest to choose what to learn first
Skip ahead to pricing before explaining the concept
copy_guidelines.example_good: Section header: 'Does this space match your schedule?' → Day badge row → Match indicator → Then: 'Now let's look at what it would cost for your specific pattern.'
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Listing page that shows price, schedule, photos, rules, host info, and protection details all at once with equal visual weight.

animation_feel.feel_description: Each section loads as the previous one is resolved — like turning pages in a conversation. Not a scroll-and-see-everything page, but a progressive reveal.

tension_relief.tension_point: Each new section heading introduces a question the guest is about to have answered
tension_relief.relief_point: The answer within that section resolves the question before the next one appears
tension_relief.timing: 5-10 seconds per question-answer cycle. The guest should never be in 'confusion' state for more than 10 seconds.

personalization_signals: Sections that are already answered by the guest's preferences are auto-resolved ('Your weekend pattern matches — next question')

anti_patterns.pattern: Showing all information at once and expecting the guest to find what they need
anti_patterns.reason: Creates cognitive overload that maintains confusion. Theodore needed 14 minutes of sequential Q&A — the UI must replicate this, not bypass it.
anti_patterns.example_bad: A listing page with 12 sections all visible simultaneously, requiring the guest to scroll and scan for relevance.
